STUDENT COUNCIL
NOMINATIONS HELD
Eight Named For President Of
Student Governing Body
ELECTIONS NEXT WEEK
Polls To Be Open From 11
A. M. To 1 P.M.
Nominations for President of the
Student Council were held at the
Assembly yesterday. A crowd of
about four hundred packed the C.
E. Hall to capacity and the result
was a greater number of nominations for the office than in many
years past.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 9, 1930

Vol. XXXIV, No. 49

LIBERALS TO HOLD
BANQUET TONIGHT
"Deceit and the Theory of
History" will be the topic of
an address to be delivered by
Frank Coe of the Institute of
Law at the annual banquet of
the John Hopkins Liberal Club
which is to be held tonight on
the second floor "of Levering
Hall. This meeting will be presided over by Joel Seidman,
president of the club, and an
election of officers for the coming year will be held. The dinner will start promptly at 6:30
and the subscription price
will be $1.00.

At a meeting of the Tudor
and Stuart Club held on Friday, May 2d, the following

President, Dr. Henry Barton

elected members of the Board
of Governors.
The club spent about $1,200
on books during the year. A
sum of $150 was invested in
the first edition of Drayton's
poems and $165 was also spent
on the first edition of the Battle of Agincourt. In all the
club bought about twelve good
books.

EDITORIALS
BANQUET SEASON

UDGING from recent occurences, a complete discontinuance of
J hostilities between the sophomore and freshman classes during
the so-called banquet season would seem wise. This year's
activities were criticized from every point of view. Those opposing all such evidences of class spirit were certainly not pleased,
while the group that favors such hostilities was disappointed because of the lack of action. Since the ruling forbidding the breaking up of banquets was passed, only complaints have been registered. This situation has become worse each year, only to reach
its lowest ebb this week.
For those who respect the old customs, everything went wrong.
Fights were apparently held, not for kidnaping, but merely for
the sake of fighting. Rules were broken in that hostilities were
continued after the deadline of 6 o'clock. Both classes seemed to
be at fault here. Furthermore, only a very small group from each
class took part in the action. Not one man, to our knowledge,
was kept from attending his banquet. Only one was late in arriving. The point of the fighting, if there is any point at all, is
to prevent the members of the two classes from attending their
respective banquets. During the last two years all efforts along
this line have been complete failures.
From what is probably a more sensible point of view, the only
results have been many minor injuries, one of a more serious nature,
and a considerable amount of ruined clothing.
It would seem apparent that there are only two ways of solving
the problem. Either repeal the ruling forbidding the breaking
up of banquets or abolish all hostilities. The former is not advisable. The amount of property destroyed, time wasted and
injuries incurred as well as the difficulties met with the civil
authorities preclude this action. Therefore we recommend that
Student Council pass a ruling forbidding all such hostilities in
the future.

LACROSSE
the Hopkins schedule for the 1930 lacrosse season
W HEN
was announced, many sports followers at the University
were dismayed. It appeared that it would be impossible for a
comparatively green Hopkins twelve to make any kind of a showing against such a formidable array of opponents.
To date this team has made a brilliant showing, defeating
every college opponent, and losing only to Mt. Washington,
probably the strongest team in the country. Furthermore this
year's twelve has shown that it has the power to go through the
remainder of its schedule without a defeat. This will, of course,
be a difficult feat to accomplish. Three of the best college team's
in the country are yet to be met. The lacrosse team deserves the
support of every undergraduate. A team that is convinced it
can't be beaten, will not be beaten. A victory in tomorrow's game
against Princeton will be an immeasurable help in firmly establishing this spirit among the members of the team. A defeat
may be disastrous.
The success of the 1930 Jay twelve is due primarily to hard
work and teamwork. Every man is in danger of losing his position if he falters. No one individual stands out as the star of
the team. A team of this type is the hardest kind of a combination to defeat. The NEWS-LETTER congratulates the team, and
is sure it will not disappoint its followers tomorrow afternoon.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 9, 1930

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
Students at the University of
Madrid engaged in a serious clash
with the police, in which two men
were killed and several others injured, including a member of the
faculty of the San Carlos Medical
College. The cause of the rioting appears to be, from a dispatch to the
Sun, the dissatisfaction of the student body towards the monarchial
regime, and avowed interest in a republican government. In order to
prevent further bloodshed, General
Berenguer declared that stern measures will have to be adopted towards
student rioting. "We have to stop
this," he asserted; "we have no other remedy—we are taking the necessary measures."
* * *

The interest aroused during the
banquet season is reaching greater
heights at other colleges than class
enthusiasim at Hopkins which is
manifested in a few half-hearted
sallies (with most of those who
should take part in the combat assuming the duties of half-hearted
spectators) the only results of which
are a few dirty trousers, an occasional R. 0. T. C. coat ripped up
the middle of the back and perhaps
a not too wary freshman handcuffed to an electric light pole or a sophomore taken for an overlong auto
ride. The struggle between the lower classes at Lafayette, which was
scheduled to begin at I. was precipitated by the average underclassmen,
so that several private engagements
were well under way at 12:30. The
R. 0. T. C. companies of the university were engaged in drill until
2:45, and many members of the unit
were seen to cast longing eyes at the
scene of mortal combat, in which
they took part after drill and a
change from uniform to classstruggle "armor." At the close of
the battle, when the last sounds of
conflict had died away from the
campus, the second-year men were
declared victorious, by virtue of
having secured eight more captives
than the yearlings. Despite their defeat of the afternoon, the frosh
showed great activity at their banquet, which approximately 150 attended.
* * *

Upholding the other side of the
question of inter-class fighting, we
find a vigorous exponent in the
Targum of Rutgers University. According to a survey made by the
Rutgers' committee of twelve, underclass warfare in American colleges and universities is a dead institution (or rather almost dead). The
"hectic days of the past decade when
sophomores pummeled freshmen"
are gone. A questionnaire was distributed by the Rutgers committee
on class warfare among the deans
of 18 colleges, including Harvard,
Princeton, Yale, Pennsylvania, and
others. Nine of the colleges have no
class warfare, and nine have freshmen and sophomore engagements in
milder forms, while one clean maintained that "undergraduate warfare
is valuable to student life and college warfare" and that he would
"hate to see it abolished." The lack
of interest of the students in such
functions is cited as the reason for
the increasing sentiment towards the
abolition of interclass struggles.
"'No sudden or sweeping reform
will be attempted here.' Will Govenor Myers Y. Cooper of Ohio, dare
use these words of one of his illustrious predecessors in regard to prison reform when the investigation of
the recent tragedy at the Ohio State
prison is over ?" The question is asked by the Brown and White of Lehigh University, in quoting a letter
of Rutherford B. Hayes. written

while Governor of Ohio in 1869, to
E. C. Wines, corresponding secretary of the New York Prison Association, on the subject of prison reform. The letter has been recently
placed on display in the new Lehigh
library, and advocates a gradual and
steady advance towards a system of
prison reform.
** *

of the drums clears the floor, the
lights are darkened, leaving only a
brilliant spot-light on the center of
the room. And then appears—but
we can't let you in on this secret for
some time. Suffice to say our entertainment will be something quite unusual and equally as enjoyable.

morning flit by one by one. Finally
the night club party is over and all
go home to snatch a few hours
sleep before the festivities of the following day.

EDITORIALS
BANQUET SEASON

UDGING from recent occurences, a complete discontinuance of
J hostilities between the sophomore and freshman classes during
the so-called banquet season would seem wise. This year's
activities were criticized from every point of view. Those opposing all such evidences of class spirit were certainly not pleased,
while the group that favors such hostilities was disappointed because of the lack of action. Since the ruling forbidding the breaking up of banquets was passed, only complaints have been registered. This situation has become worse each year, only to reach
its lowest ebb this week.
For those who respect the old customs, everything went wrong.
Fights were apparently held, not for kidnaping, but merely for
the sake of fighting. Rules were broken in that hostilities were
continued after the deadline of 6 o'clock. Both classes seemed to
be at fault here. Furthermore, only a very small group from each
class took part in the action. Not one man, to our knowledge,
was kept from attending his banquet. Only one was late in arriving. The point of the fighting, if there is any point at all, is
to prevent the members of the two classes from attending their
respective banquets. During the last two years all efforts along
this line have been complete failures.
From what is probably a more sensible point of view, the only
results have been many minor injuries, one of a more serious nature,
and a considerable amount of ruined clothing.
It would seem apparent that there are only two ways of solving
the problem. Either repeal the ruling forbidding the breaking
up of banquets or abolish all hostilities. The former is not advisable. The amount of property destroyed, time wasted and
injuries incurred as well as the difficulties met with the civil
authorities preclude this action. Therefore we recommend that
Student Council pass a ruling forbidding all such hostilities in
the future.

LACROSSE
the Hopkins schedule for the 1930 lacrosse season
W HEN
was announced, many sports followers at the University
were dismayed. It appeared that it would be impossible for a
comparatively green Hopkins twelve to make any kind of a showing against such a formidable array of opponents.
To date this team has made a brilliant showing, defeating
every college opponent, and losing only to Mt. Washington,
probably the strongest team in the country. Furthermore this
year's twelve has shown that it has the power to go through the
remainder of its schedule without a defeat. This will, of course,
be a difficult feat to accomplish. Three of the best college team's
in the country are yet to be met. The lacrosse team deserves the
support of every undergraduate. A team that is convinced it
can't be beaten, will not be beaten. A victory in tomorrow's game
against Princeton will be an immeasurable help in firmly establishing this spirit among the members of the team. A defeat
may be disastrous.
The success of the 1930 Jay twelve is due primarily to hard
work and teamwork. Every man is in danger of losing his position if he falters. No one individual stands out as the star of
the team. A team of this type is the hardest kind of a combination to defeat. The NEWS-LETTER congratulates the team, and
is sure it will not disappoint its followers tomorrow afternoon.

If you're the kind of man who has said to

he wants to shine—a college man with a

will learn advertising under some of Baltimore's most successful advertising men.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 9, 1930

INTERCOLLEGIATE NEWS
Students at the University of
Madrid engaged in a serious clash
with the police, in which two men
were killed and several others injured, including a member of the
faculty of the San Carlos Medical
College. The cause of the rioting appears to be, from a dispatch to the
Sun, the dissatisfaction of the student body towards the monarchial
regime, and avowed interest in a republican government. In order to
prevent further bloodshed, General
Berenguer declared that stern measures will have to be adopted towards
student rioting. "We have to stop
this," he asserted; "we have no other remedy—we are taking the necessary measures."
* * *

The interest aroused during the
banquet season is reaching greater
heights at other colleges than class
enthusiasim at Hopkins which is
manifested in a few half-hearted
sallies (with most of those who
should take part in the combat assuming the duties of half-hearted
spectators) the only results of which
are a few dirty trousers, an occasional R. 0. T. C. coat ripped up
the middle of the back and perhaps
a not too wary freshman handcuffed to an electric light pole or a sophomore taken for an overlong auto
ride. The struggle between the lower classes at Lafayette, which was
scheduled to begin at I. was precipitated by the average underclassmen,
so that several private engagements
were well under way at 12:30. The
R. 0. T. C. companies of the university were engaged in drill until
2:45, and many members of the unit
were seen to cast longing eyes at the
scene of mortal combat, in which
they took part after drill and a
change from uniform to classstruggle "armor." At the close of
the battle, when the last sounds of
conflict had died away from the
campus, the second-year men were
declared victorious, by virtue of
having secured eight more captives
than the yearlings. Despite their defeat of the afternoon, the frosh
showed great activity at their banquet, which approximately 150 attended.
* * *

Upholding the other side of the
question of inter-class fighting, we
find a vigorous exponent in the
Targum of Rutgers University. According to a survey made by the
Rutgers' committee of twelve, underclass warfare in American colleges and universities is a dead institution (or rather almost dead). The
"hectic days of the past decade when
sophomores pummeled freshmen"
are gone. A questionnaire was distributed by the Rutgers committee
on class warfare among the deans
of 18 colleges, including Harvard,
Princeton, Yale, Pennsylvania, and
others. Nine of the colleges have no
class warfare, and nine have freshmen and sophomore engagements in
milder forms, while one clean maintained that "undergraduate warfare
is valuable to student life and college warfare" and that he would
"hate to see it abolished." The lack
of interest of the students in such
functions is cited as the reason for
the increasing sentiment towards the
abolition of interclass struggles.
"'No sudden or sweeping reform
will be attempted here.' Will Govenor Myers Y. Cooper of Ohio, dare
use these words of one of his illustrious predecessors in regard to prison reform when the investigation of
the recent tragedy at the Ohio State
prison is over ?" The question is asked by the Brown and White of Lehigh University, in quoting a letter
of Rutherford B. Hayes. written

while Governor of Ohio in 1869, to
E. C. Wines, corresponding secretary of the New York Prison Association, on the subject of prison reform. The letter has been recently
placed on display in the new Lehigh
library, and advocates a gradual and
steady advance towards a system of
prison reform.

Meanwhile others have joined our
original group. They choose tables,
seat themselves, and prepare for
an evening of pleasure. The orchestra breaks into the newest bit, couples rise here and there and begin
dancingt Soon the floor is filled
with people who, from the hour of
their arrival, have become ardent
devotees of the Great Goddess Terpsichore.
The merriment goes on, increasing as the hours roll on. Hardly
anyone realizes that it is now midnight and that the dance has been in
full swing for several hours. A roll
of the drums clears the floor, the
lights are darkened, leaving only a
brilliant spot-light on the center of
the room. And then appears—but
we can't let you in on this secret for
some time. Suffice to say our entertainment will be something quite unusual and equally as enjoyable.
More dancing, more entertainment more dancing, still more entertainment as the wee hours of the
morning flit by one by one. Finally
the night club party is over and all
go home to snatch a few hours
sleep before the festivities of the following day.
